The National Association of Educational Broadcasters has re¬
ceived $42,738 from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation for the
year 1959-60* Dr* Harry J. Skomia, Executive Director
of the NAEB, said this is the first payment of a three-year
grant totaling $106,338.
With a Kellogg grant in 1951, the NAEB set up its national
headquarters and permanent staff, as well as a national
educational radio network. The network became self-support¬
ing within five years, and now distributes recorded educa¬
tional programs at the rate of a thousand tape recordings a
week.
While NAEB headquarters is slowly achieving self-support
itself, part of the present grant will be used to carry on
its regular services* Dr. Skomia said that the funds will
allow the NAEB to hire a full-time editor for its various
publications. NAEB will also use the grant to conduct
seminars each year for advanced training of personnel within
the field of educational radio and television.
